Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Brain Metabolic Plasticity and Agression
Award.AbstractNarration:
A key challenge in biology is to understand the link between brain function and behavior. Knowledge of brain functional dynamics is especially important for understanding how experience shapes the brain. This project couples state-of-the-art techniques to measure and mathematically model brain metabolic activity, using the honey bee as a model system and aggression as the focal behavior. Experiments will determine whether experimentally induced changes in brain metabolism cause changes in aggression, which is what is expected based on previously collected correlative data. Additional experiments will determine in which parts of the brain are the aggression-related changes in metabolic activity. This new information will then be used to build a comprehensive model of the bee brain's metabolic network, which will then be validated with experimental work.

This collaborative project will provide integrative training for undergraduate students, graduate students, and post-doctoral associates, and members of the research team will give public presentations on the new insights into brain function gained by this project in a variety of venues for retired people and in K-12 settings. The Institute for Genomic Biology (IGB) at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign will be the facility to store and back up project data, which include mainly RNA bioinformatic sequence-based and metabolomic datasets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported new research that has resulted in a new understanding of the relationship between brain metabolism and aggression. It has sparked new research on nutrition and how it affects brain metabolism. It also has opened new lines of question on how brain metabolism affects brain neurochemistry. Specifically, the issue is whether the changes in brain metabolism associated with aggression reflect changes in the energy requirements of neurons during aggressive arousal and responsiveness to social challenges, or ehther the changes in brain metabolism reflect changes in the relative synthesis of key neurotransmitters such as GABA and glutamate. Our metabolomics research support the second alternative, but more research will be required. 

 

This research also sparked comparative neurogenomic research that resulted in the identification of similar changes in the brains of mice and stickleback fish. This points to a deeply conserved evolutionary response to social challenge.

 

This new knowledge was disseminated through peer-review publication, presentation at scientific meetings and at universities.

 

This grant also supported the professional development of a young female scientist who has gone on to establish her own lab at a different university and a female undergraduate who went on to receive training in science writing and now works in the field.
